chunks.en: Intelligent driving is very popular now, so I want to ask, how many people dare to use it, and what are the usage scenarios?
As the title says, I'm not comfortable entrusting the lives of my family to it.
Use it on the highway every day.
Now they call ACC intelligent driving ğŸ˜„~

No, have you used it? Leaving aside city intelligent driving, using intelligent driving on the highway directly frees up your feet, okay? If your feet can move, you can also move your waist. People who have really driven a car know that the most tiring part of driving is the waist. Anyway, I always turn on intelligent driving when I get on the highway for maximum comfort.

I've been using it for almost ten years. The standard intelligent driving of each company is adaptive driving ACC + lane centering + active braking from the fuel car era. It used to be available for extra money on fuel cars. It's a very mature technology, but it has been marketed in the new energy vehicle era. Plus, many people in the fuel car era didn't choose to install this, so they never came into contact with it, so when they switched to new energy, they felt that the basic version of intelligent driving was a new thing. The truly epoch-making one is fully intelligent driving. It would be smooth if it could be widely popularized within 5 years, which is not the same thing you want to ask.
Those who use it are brainwashed. Awakened people definitely don't use it (except for fsd).

Highways can really reduce driving fatigue. Students who haven't used it, don't think 'use = completely ignore'. The current situation is like this: use it (eyes also staring at the road conditions ahead, ready to take over in special circumstances), and this has greatly reduced driving fatigue. I have severe myopia and used to avoid driving at night as much as possible. Driving more than 200 kilometers on the highway during the day would make my back ache, but now I dare to drive at night with intelligent driving, and I even feel like I can do 1000 kilometers (although I haven't tried it).
@wxw752 You are not only speeding and breaking the law, but also endangering people with your 'blades'. I hope you will bear the consequences soon. Blocked.
@wxw752 Driving at 150 on the highway is not something to brag about... Setting it to 130 is reasonable.
Unless the car company promises full compensation in the event of an accident, then I'll use it.

I use it when the road conditions are good (few pedestrians and non-motor vehicles). This thing is the same as high-speed ACC. Just pay attention to manual supervision and intervention when using it. No one asks you to sleep in the car and let go. Intelligent driving is something that you disdain before using it, but you love and can't go back after using it.

I now use intelligent driving for 70% of my highway driving. As the person above said, use â‰  ignore. When driving, my mind is focused, and my body is relaxed. I take over as soon as I sense danger. After hundreds of kilometers, my back and legs used to ache, but now I'm very relaxed and have a good spirit.

chunks.en: The definition of 'intelligent driving' itself is problematic. 'Assisted driving' is a more accurate description for the average person. I will definitely not use NOA point-to-point driving, as I am betting my life. It is also not realistic unless more than 90% of the cars on the market have this function enabled. Even APA automatic parking is rarely used. It is mainly the ACC adaptive cruise control system combined with LCC lane centering assist that I use every day. There are also some intelligent driving functions that I basically never use and don't want to use, but they are always protecting us.

@nuomi196500 @wxw752 You should at least go for a test drive, or at least watch a video for a cloud experience. The adaptive driving of old-fashioned BBAs can only maintain the lane + emergency braking. The problem is, what if you stop suddenly when encountering an obstacle and the car behind you crashes into you? A small car behind you is fine, anyway. If it is crashed into scrap, it is their primary responsibility, and it is a rear-end collision. But what if it is a truck? It's useless if you don't have the function of actively avoiding risks. Also, if you say you are staring at it all the time and controlling it at any time, you will find that this function is useless, and you will be more tired. It is better to drive yourself, constantly worrying. Finally, the lane keeping function is only applicable to clearly marked road sections. In the current highway conditions, you will encounter road construction on 100% of the sections exceeding 300KM.
@helone #75 I'm too lazy to discuss it, but you still @ me. Don't do it next time. You have no fighting power at all.

@wxw752 #80 If it were a few years earlier, I would definitely help you find a bunch of actual test videos. Now my opinion is that from the moment we start arguing with xx, we have actually lost. You like it, that's good. Best wishes.

@helone #95 No problem, just don't @ me next time. Passing the hard time by slacking off. A personality like yours can't last a few minutes. There's no problem with being self-righteous, but you shouldn't have posted such a long paragraph in the first place. You're not skilled enough, you need to restrain yourself.

@helone First, I am a hybrid car owner. I have driven Xiaopeng/Li Auto electric cars, and currently drive a Tesla. I don't need cloud experience. I experience it every day. My experience is that the car following experience is exactly the same when driving. Second, the industry defines ACC as an important part of assisted driving. The functions you mentioned can only be regarded as icing on the cake. In essence, ACC is still playing the most core role. There is still a long way to go before true fully autonomous driving. Third, fuel car ACCs also have different prices. At least the one I am currently driving has automatic lane change, avoidance, side collision prevention, entering and exiting ramps, etc. Fourth, I don't understand why some people, as consumers, can't stand others normally discussing and viewing the things they buy, including but not limited to cars, mobile phones, cameras, etc. It's a very strange mentality.

@letwewell This kind of mentality is unacceptable. Money can be compensated, but life cannot. You have to be responsible for your own safety. Personally, I don't like the word 'intelligent driving'. It is essentially assisted driving. Autonomous driving is even more of a scam.

@iwantcomputer Your understanding is inaccurate. The biggest difference between LCC and intelligent driving is whether the car knows where you want to go. L2 assisted driving, that is, adaptive cruise + lane keeping, has already been popularized.
Feel free to use L2 assisted driving from major domestic car companies, but I don't trust any intelligent driving, including assisted driving, from foreign countries (Volvo, Toyota, BMW, etc.).
